1923
1924struct DNSQuestion_struct
1925{
1926 // Internal state fields. These are used internally by mDNSCore; the client layer needn't be concerned with them.
1927 DNSQuestion *next;
1928 mDNSu32 qnamehash;
1929 mDNSs32 DelayAnswering; // Set if we want to defer answering this question until the cache settles
1930 mDNSs32 LastQTime; // Last scheduled transmission of this Q on *all* applicable interfaces
1931 mDNSs32 ThisQInterval; // LastQTime + ThisQInterval is the next scheduled transmission of this Q
1932 // ThisQInterval > 0 for an active question;
1933 // ThisQInterval = 0 for a suspended question that's still in the list
1934 // ThisQInterval = -1 for a cancelled question (should not still be in list)
1935 mDNSs32 ExpectUnicastResp; // Set when we send a query with the kDNSQClass_UnicastResponse bit set
1936 mDNSs32 LastAnswerPktNum; // The sequence number of the last response packet containing an answer to this Q
1937 mDNSu32 RecentAnswerPkts; // Number of answers since the last time we sent this query
1938 mDNSu32 CurrentAnswers; // Number of records currently in the cache that answer this question
1939 mDNSu32 BrowseThreshold; // If we have received at least this number of answers,
1940 // set the next question interval to MaxQuestionInterval
1941 mDNSu32 LargeAnswers; // Number of answers with rdata > 1024 bytes
1942 mDNSu32 UniqueAnswers; // Number of answers received with kDNSClass_UniqueRRSet bit set
1943 mDNSInterfaceID FlappingInterface1; // Set when an interface goes away, to flag if remove events are delivered for this Q
1944 mDNSInterfaceID FlappingInterface2; // Set when an interface goes away, to flag if remove events are delivered for this Q
1945 DomainAuthInfo *AuthInfo; // Non-NULL if query is currently being done using Private DNS
1946 DNSQuestion *DuplicateOf;
1947 DNSQuestion *NextInDQList;
1948 AnonymousInfo *AnonInfo; // Anonymous Information
1949 DupSuppressInfo DupSuppress[DupSuppressInfoSize];
1950 mDNSInterfaceID SendQNow; // The interface this query is being sent on right now
1951 mDNSBool SendOnAll; // Set if we're sending this question on all active interfaces
1952 mDNSBool CachedAnswerNeedsUpdate; // See SendQueries(). Set if we're sending this question
1953 // because a cached answer needs to be refreshed.
1954 mDNSu32 RequestUnicast; // Non-zero if we want to send query with kDNSQClass_UnicastResponse bit set
1955 mDNSs32 LastQTxTime; // Last time this Q was sent on one (but not necessarily all) interfaces
1956 mDNSu32 CNAMEReferrals; // Count of how many CNAME redirections we've done
1957 mDNSBool SuppressQuery; // This query should be suppressed and not sent on the wire
1958 mDNSu8 LOAddressAnswers; // Number of answers from the local only auth records that are
1959 // answering A, AAAA, CNAME, or PTR (/etc/hosts)
1960 mDNSu8 WakeOnResolveCount; // Number of wakes that should be sent on resolve
1961 mDNSs32 StopTime; // Time this question should be stopped by giving them a negative answer
1962
1963 // DNSSEC fields
1964 DNSSECValState ValidationState; // Current state of the Validation process
1965 DNSSECStatus ValidationStatus; // Validation status for "ValidationRequired" questions (dnssec)
1966 mDNSu8 ValidatingResponse; // Question trying to validate a response (dnssec) on behalf of
1967 // ValidationRequired question
1968 void *DNSSECAuthInfo;
1969 DNSSECAuthInfoFreeCallback *DAIFreeCallback;
1970
1971 // Wide Area fields. These are used internally by the uDNS core (Unicast)
1972 UDPSocket *LocalSocket;
1973
1974 // |-> DNS Configuration related fields used in uDNS (Subset of Wide Area/Unicast fields)
1975 DNSServer *qDNSServer; // Caching server for this query (in the absence of an SRV saying otherwise)
1976 mDNSOpaque128 validDNSServers; // Valid DNSServers for this question
1977 mDNSu16 noServerResponse; // At least one server did not respond.
1978 mDNSu16 triedAllServersOnce; // Tried all DNS servers once
1979 mDNSu8 unansweredQueries; // The number of unanswered queries to this server
1980
1981 ZoneData *nta; // Used for getting zone data for private or LLQ query
1982 mDNSAddr servAddr; // Address and port learned from _dns-llq, _dns-llq-tls or _dns-query-tls SRV query
1983 mDNSIPPort servPort;
1984 struct tcpInfo_t *tcp;
1985 mDNSIPPort tcpSrcPort; // Local Port TCP packet received on;need this as tcp struct is disposed
1986 // by tcpCallback before calling into mDNSCoreReceive
1987 mDNSu8 NoAnswer; // Set if we want to suppress answers until tunnel setup has completed
1988 mDNSu8 Restart; // This question should be restarted soon
1989
1990 // LLQ-specific fields. These fields are only meaningful when LongLived flag is set
1991 LLQ_State state;
1992 mDNSu32 ReqLease; // seconds (relative)
1993 mDNSs32 expire; // ticks (absolute)
1994 mDNSs16 ntries; // for UDP: the number of packets sent for this LLQ state
1995 // for TCP: there is some ambiguity in the use of this variable, but in general, it is
1996 // the number of TCP/TLS connection attempts for this LLQ state, or
1997 // the number of packets sent for this TCP/TLS connection
1998
1999 // DNS Push Notification fields. These fields are only meaningful when LongLived flag is set
2000 DNSPush_State dnsPushState; // The state of the DNS push notification negotiation
2001 mDNSAddr dnsPushServerAddr; // Address of the system acting as the DNS Push Server
2002 mDNSIPPort dnsPushServerPort; // Port on which the DNS Push Server is being advertised.
2003
2004 mDNSOpaque64 id;
2005
2006 // DNS Proxy fields
2007 mDNSOpaque16 responseFlags; // Temporary place holder for the error we get back from the DNS server
2008 // till we populate in the cache
2009 mDNSBool DisallowPID; // Is the query allowed for the "PID" that we are sending on behalf of ?
2010 mDNSs32 ServiceID; // Service identifier to match against the DNS server
2011
2012 // Client API fields: The client must set up these fields *before* calling mDNS_StartQuery()
2013 mDNSInterfaceID InterfaceID; // Non-zero if you want to issue queries only on a single specific IP interface
2014 mDNSu32 flags; // flags from original DNSService*() API request.
2015 mDNSAddr Target; // Non-zero if you want to direct queries to a specific unicast target address
2016 mDNSIPPort TargetPort; // Must be set if Target is set
2017 mDNSOpaque16 TargetQID; // Must be set if Target is set
2018 domainname qname;
2019 mDNSu16 qtype;
2020 mDNSu16 qclass;
2021 mDNSBool LongLived; // Set by client for calls to mDNS_StartQuery to indicate LLQs to unicast layer.
2022 mDNSBool ExpectUnique; // Set by client if it's expecting unique RR(s) for this question, not shared RRs
2023 mDNSBool ForceMCast; // Set by client to force mDNS query, even for apparently uDNS names
2024 mDNSBool ReturnIntermed; // Set by client to request callbacks for intermediate CNAME/NXDOMAIN results
2025 mDNSBool SuppressUnusable; // Set by client to suppress unusable queries to be sent on the wire
2026 mDNSu8 RetryWithSearchDomains; // Retry with search domains if there is no entry in the cache or AuthRecords
2027 mDNSu8 TimeoutQuestion; // Timeout this question if there is no reply in configured time
2028 mDNSu8 WakeOnResolve; // Send wakeup on resolve
2029 mDNSu8 UseBackgroundTrafficClass; // Set by client to use background traffic class for request
2030 mDNSs8 SearchListIndex; // Index into SearchList; Used by the client layer but not touched by core
2031 mDNSs8 AppendSearchDomains; // Search domains can be appended for this query
2032 mDNSs8 AppendLocalSearchDomains; // Search domains ending in .local can be appended for this query
2033 mDNSu8 ValidationRequired; // Requires DNSSEC validation.
2034 mDNSu8 ProxyQuestion; // Proxy Question
2035 mDNSu8 ProxyDNSSECOK; // Proxy Question with EDNS0 DNSSEC OK bit set
2036 mDNSs32 pid; // Process ID of the client that is requesting the question
2037 mDNSu8 uuid[UUID_SIZE]; // Unique ID of the client that is requesting the question (valid only if pid is zero)
2038 mDNSu32 euid; // Effective User Id of the client that is requesting the question
2039 domainname *qnameOrig; // Copy of the original question name if it is not fully qualified
2040 mDNSQuestionCallback *QuestionCallback;
2041 void *QuestionContext;
2042#if AWD_METRICS
2043 uDNSMetrics metrics; // Data used for collecting unicast DNS query metrics.
2044#endif
2045#if USE_DNS64
2046 DNS64 dns64; // DNS64 state for performing IPv6 address synthesis on networks with NAT64.
2047#endif
2048};

2054struct ZoneData_struct
2055{
2056 domainname ChildName; // Name for which we're trying to find the responsible server
2057 ZoneService ZoneService; // Which service we're seeking for this zone (update, query, or LLQ)
2058 domainname *CurrentSOA; // Points to somewhere within ChildName
2059 domainname ZoneName; // Discovered result: Left-hand-side of SOA record
2060 mDNSu16 ZoneClass; // Discovered result: DNS Class from SOA record
2061 domainname Host; // Discovered result: Target host from SRV record
2062 mDNSIPPort Port; // Discovered result: Update port, query port, or LLQ port from SRV record
2063 mDNSAddr Addr; // Discovered result: Address of Target host from SRV record
2064 mDNSBool ZonePrivate; // Discovered result: Does zone require encrypted queries?
2065 ZoneDataCallback *ZoneDataCallback; // Caller-specified function to be called upon completion
2066 void *ZoneDataContext;
2067 DNSQuestion question; // Storage for any active question
2068};

2083#define TC_STATE_AAAA_PEER 0x000000001 /* Peer's BTMM IPv6 address */

2088typedef struct ClientTunnel
2089{
2090 struct ClientTunnel *next;
2091 domainname dstname;
2092 mDNSBool MarkedForDeletion;
2093 mDNSv6Addr loc_inner;
2094 mDNSv4Addr loc_outer;
2095 mDNSv6Addr loc_outer6;
2096 mDNSv6Addr rmt_inner;
2097 mDNSv4Addr rmt_outer;
2098 mDNSv6Addr rmt_outer6;
2099 mDNSIPPort rmt_outer_port;
2100 mDNSu16 tc_state;
2101 DNSQuestion q;
2102} ClientTunnel;
2103#endif

2105// ***************************************************************************
2106#if 0
2107#pragma mark -
2108#pragma mark - NetworkInterfaceInfo_struct
2109#endif
2110
2111typedef struct NetworkInterfaceInfo_struct NetworkInterfaceInfo;
2112
2113// A NetworkInterfaceInfo_struct serves two purposes:
2114// 1. It holds the address, PTR and HINFO records to advertise a given IP address on a given physical interface
2115// 2. It tells mDNSCore which physical interfaces are available; each physical interface has its own unique InterfaceID.
2116// Since there may be multiple IP addresses on a single physical interface,
2117// there may be multiple NetworkInterfaceInfo_structs with the same InterfaceID.
2118// In this case, to avoid sending the same packet n times, when there's more than one
2119// struct with the same InterfaceID, mDNSCore picks one member of the set to be the
2120// active representative of the set; all others have the 'InterfaceActive' flag unset.
2121
2122struct NetworkInterfaceInfo_struct
2123{
2124 // Internal state fields. These are used internally by mDNSCore; the client layer needn't be concerned with them.
2125 NetworkInterfaceInfo *next;
2126
2127 mDNSu8 InterfaceActive; // Set if interface is sending & receiving packets (see comment above)
2128 mDNSu8 IPv4Available; // If InterfaceActive, set if v4 available on this InterfaceID
2129 mDNSu8 IPv6Available; // If InterfaceActive, set if v6 available on this InterfaceID
2130
2131 DNSQuestion NetWakeBrowse;
2132 DNSQuestion NetWakeResolve[3]; // For fault-tolerance, we try up to three Sleep Proxies
2133 mDNSAddr SPSAddr[3];
2134 mDNSIPPort SPSPort[3];
2135 mDNSs32 NextSPSAttempt; // -1 if we're not currently attempting to register with any Sleep Proxy
2136 mDNSs32 NextSPSAttemptTime;
2137
2138 // Standard AuthRecords that every Responder host should have (one per active IP address)
2139 AuthRecord RR_A; // 'A' or 'AAAA' (address) record for our ".local" name
2140 AuthRecord RR_PTR; // PTR (reverse lookup) record
2141 AuthRecord RR_HINFO;
2142
2143 // Client API fields: The client must set up these fields *before* calling mDNS_RegisterInterface()
2144 mDNSInterfaceID InterfaceID; // Identifies physical interface; MUST NOT be 0, -1, or -2
2145 mDNSAddr ip; // The IPv4 or IPv6 address to advertise
2146 mDNSAddr mask;
2147 mDNSEthAddr MAC;
2148 char ifname[64]; // Windows uses a GUID string for the interface name, which doesn't fit in 16 bytes
2149 mDNSu8 Advertise; // False if you are only searching on this interface
2150 mDNSu8 McastTxRx; // Send/Receive multicast on this { InterfaceID, address family } ?
2151 mDNSu8 NetWake; // Set if Wake-On-Magic-Packet is enabled on this interface
2152 mDNSu8 Loopback; // Set if this is the loopback interface
2153 mDNSu8 IgnoreIPv4LL; // Set if IPv4 Link-Local addresses have to be ignored.
2154 mDNSu8 SendGoodbyes; // Send goodbyes on this interface while sleeping
2155 mDNSBool DirectLink; // a direct link, indicating we can skip the probe for
2156 // address records
2157 mDNSBool SupportsUnicastMDNSResponse; // Indicates that the interface supports unicast responses
2158 // to Bonjour queries. Generally true for an interface.
2159};
2160
2161#define SLE_DELETE 0x00000001
2162#define SLE_WAB_BROWSE_QUERY_STARTED 0x00000002
2163#define SLE_WAB_LBROWSE_QUERY_STARTED 0x00000004
2164#define SLE_WAB_REG_QUERY_STARTED 0x00000008

2171 mDNSInterfaceID InterfaceID;

2184// to discover recommended domains for domain enumeration (browse, default browse, registration,
2185// default registration) and possibly one or more recommended automatic browsing domains.

2353 mDNSs32 PktNum; // Unique sequence number assigned to each received packet
2354 mDNSs32 MPktNum; // Unique sequence number assigned to each received Multicast packet
2355 mDNSu8 LocalRemoveEvents; // Set if we may need to deliver remove events for local-only questions and/or local-only records

2358 mDNSu8 SystemWakeOnLANEnabled; // Set if we want to register with a Sleep Proxy before going to sleep
2359 mDNSu8 SentSleepProxyRegistration; // Set if we registered (or tried to register) with a Sleep Proxy
2360 mDNSu8 SystemSleepOnlyIfWakeOnLAN; // Set if we may only sleep if we managed to register with a Sleep Proxy
2361 mDNSs32 AnnounceOwner; // After waking from sleep, include OWNER option in packets until this time
2362 mDNSs32 DelaySleep; // To inhibit re-sleeping too quickly right after wake
2363 mDNSs32 SleepLimit; // Time window to allow deregistrations, etc.,
2364 // during which underying platform layer should inhibit system sleep
2365 mDNSs32 TimeSlept; // Time we went to sleep.
2366

2369 mDNSs32 RemoteSubnet; // Multicast packets received from outside our subnet.

2521#define FORALL_CACHERECORDS(SLOT,CG,CR) \
2522 for ((SLOT) = 0; (SLOT) < CACHE_HASH_SLOTS; (SLOT)++) \
2523 for ((CG)=m->rrcache_hash[(SLOT)]; (CG); (CG)=(CG)->next) \
2524 for ((CR) = (CG)->members; (CR); (CR)=(CR)->next)

2613extern mDNSs32 NonZeroTime(mDNSs32 t);

2615extern mDNSOpaque16 mDNSOpaque16fromIntVal(mDNSu16 v);

2618// If we're compiling the particular C file that instantiates our inlines, then we
2619// define "mDNSinline" (to empty string) so that we generate code in the following section
2620#if (!defined(mDNSinline) && mDNS_InstantiateInlines)
2621#define mDNSinline
2622#endif
2623
2624#ifdef mDNSinline
2625
2626mDNSinline mDNSs32 NonZeroTime(mDNSs32 t) { if (t) return(t);else return(1);}
2627
2628mDNSinline mDNSu16 mDNSVal16(mDNSOpaque16 x) { return((mDNSu16)((mDNSu16)x.b[0] << 8 | (mDNSu16)x.b[1])); }
2629
2630mDNSinline mDNSOpaque16 mDNSOpaque16fromIntVal(mDNSu16 v)
2631{
2632 mDNSOpaque16 x;
2633 x.b[0] = (mDNSu8)(v >> 8);
2634 x.b[1] = (mDNSu8)(v & 0xFF);
2635 return(x);
2636}
2637
2638#endif

2640// ***************************************************************************
2641#if 0
2642#pragma mark -
2643#pragma mark - Main Client Functions
2644#endif
2645
2646// Every client should call mDNS_Init, passing in storage for the mDNS object and the mDNS_PlatformSupport object.
2647//
2648// Clients that are only advertising services should use mDNS_Init_NoCache and mDNS_Init_ZeroCacheSize.
2649// Clients that plan to perform queries (mDNS_StartQuery, mDNS_StartBrowse, etc.)
2650// need to provide storage for the resource record cache, or the query calls will return 'mStatus_NoCache'.
2651// The rrcachestorage parameter is the address of memory for the resource record cache, and
2652// the rrcachesize parameter is the number of entries in the CacheRecord array passed in.
2653// (i.e. the size of the cache memory needs to be sizeof(CacheRecord) * rrcachesize).
2654// OS X 10.3 Panther uses an initial cache size of 64 entries, and then mDNSCore sends an
2655// mStatus_GrowCache message if it needs more.
2656//
2657// Most clients should use mDNS_Init_AdvertiseLocalAddresses. This causes mDNSCore to automatically
2658// create the correct address records for all the hosts interfaces. If you plan to advertise
2659// services being offered by the local machine, this is almost always what you want.
2660// There are two cases where you might use mDNS_Init_DontAdvertiseLocalAddresses:
2661// 1. A client-only device, that browses for services but doesn't advertise any of its own.
2662// 2. A proxy-registration service, that advertises services being offered by other machines, and takes
2663// the appropriate steps to manually create the correct address records for those other machines.
2664// In principle, a proxy-like registration service could manually create address records for its own machine too,
2665// but this would be pointless extra effort when using mDNS_Init_AdvertiseLocalAddresses does that for you.
2666//
2667// Note that a client-only device that wishes to prohibit multicast advertisements (e.g. from
2668// higher-layer API calls) must also set DivertMulticastAdvertisements in the mDNS structure and
2669// advertise local address(es) on a loopback interface.
2670//
2671// When mDNS has finished setting up the client's callback is called
2672// A client can also spin and poll the mDNSPlatformStatus field to see when it changes from mStatus_Waiting to mStatus_NoError
2673//
2674// Call mDNS_StartExit to tidy up before exiting
2675// Because exiting may be an asynchronous process (e.g. if unicast records need to be deregistered)
2676// client layer may choose to wait until mDNS_ExitNow() returns true before calling mDNS_FinalExit().
2677//
2678// Call mDNS_Register with a completed AuthRecord object to register a resource record
2679// If the resource record type is kDNSRecordTypeUnique (or kDNSknownunique) then if a conflicting resource record is discovered,
2680// the resource record's mDNSRecordCallback will be called with error code mStatus_NameConflict. The callback should deregister
2681// the record, and may then try registering the record again after picking a new name (e.g. by automatically appending a number).
2682// Following deregistration, the RecordCallback will be called with result mStatus_MemFree to signal that it is safe to deallocate
2683// the record's storage (memory must be freed asynchronously to allow for goodbye packets and dynamic update deregistration).
2684//
2685// Call mDNS_StartQuery to initiate a query. mDNS will proceed to issue Multicast DNS query packets, and any time a response
2686// is received containing a record which matches the question, the DNSQuestion's mDNSAnswerCallback function will be called
2687// Call mDNS_StopQuery when no more answers are required
2688//
2689// Care should be taken on multi-threaded or interrupt-driven environments.
2690// The main mDNS routines call mDNSPlatformLock() on entry and mDNSPlatformUnlock() on exit;
2691// each platform layer needs to implement these appropriately for its respective platform.
2692// For example, if the support code on a particular platform implements timer callbacks at interrupt time, then
2693// mDNSPlatformLock/Unlock need to disable interrupts or do similar concurrency control to ensure that the mDNS
2694// code is not entered by an interrupt-time timer callback while in the middle of processing a client call.
2695
2696extern mStatus mDNS_Init (mDNS *const m, mDNS_PlatformSupport *const p,
2697 CacheEntity *rrcachestorage, mDNSu32 rrcachesize,
2698 mDNSBool AdvertiseLocalAddresses,
2699 mDNSCallback *Callback, void *Context);
2700// See notes above on use of NoCache/ZeroCacheSize
2701#define mDNS_Init_NoCache mDNSNULL
2702#define mDNS_Init_ZeroCacheSize 0
2703// See notes above on use of Advertise/DontAdvertiseLocalAddresses
2704#define mDNS_Init_AdvertiseLocalAddresses mDNStrue
2705#define mDNS_Init_DontAdvertiseLocalAddresses mDNSfalse
2706#define mDNS_Init_NoInitCallback mDNSNULL
2707#define mDNS_Init_NoInitCallbackContext mDNSNULL
2708
2709extern void mDNS_ConfigChanged(mDNS *const m);
2710extern void mDNS_GrowCache (mDNS *const m, CacheEntity *storage, mDNSu32 numrecords);
2711extern void mDNS_StartExit (mDNS *const m);
2712extern void mDNS_FinalExit (mDNS *const m);
2713#define mDNS_Close(m) do { mDNS_StartExit(m); mDNS_FinalExit(m); } while(0)
2714#define mDNS_ExitNow(m, now) ((now) - (m)->ShutdownTime >= 0 || (!(m)->ResourceRecords))
2715
2716extern mDNSs32 mDNS_Execute (mDNS *const m);
2717
2718extern mStatus mDNS_Register (mDNS *const m, AuthRecord *const rr);
2719extern mStatus mDNS_Update (mDNS *const m, AuthRecord *const rr, mDNSu32 newttl,
2720 const mDNSu16 newrdlength, RData *const newrdata, mDNSRecordUpdateCallback *Callback);
2721extern mStatus mDNS_Deregister(mDNS *const m, AuthRecord *const rr);
2722
2723extern mStatus mDNS_StartQuery(mDNS *const m, DNSQuestion *const question);
2724extern mStatus mDNS_StopQuery (mDNS *const m, DNSQuestion *const question);
2725extern mStatus mDNS_StopQueryWithRemoves(mDNS *const m, DNSQuestion *const question);
2726extern mStatus mDNS_Reconfirm (mDNS *const m, CacheRecord *const cacherr);
2727extern mStatus mDNS_Reconfirm_internal(mDNS *const m, CacheRecord *const rr, mDNSu32 interval);
2728extern mStatus mDNS_ReconfirmByValue(mDNS *const m, ResourceRecord *const rr);
2729extern void mDNS_PurgeCacheResourceRecord(mDNS *const m, CacheRecord *rr);
2730extern mDNSs32 mDNS_TimeNow(const mDNS *const m);
2731
2732extern mStatus mDNS_StartNATOperation(mDNS *const m, NATTraversalInfo *traversal);
2733extern mStatus mDNS_StopNATOperation(mDNS *const m, NATTraversalInfo *traversal);
2734extern mStatus mDNS_StopNATOperation_internal(mDNS *m, NATTraversalInfo *traversal);

2754// mDNS_Dereg_normal is used for most calls to mDNS_Deregister_internal
2755// mDNS_Dereg_rapid is used to send one goodbye instead of three, when we want the memory available for reuse sooner
2756// mDNS_Dereg_conflict is used to indicate that this record is being forcibly deregistered because of a conflict
2757// mDNS_Dereg_repeat is used when cleaning up, for records that may have already been forcibly deregistered
2758typedef enum { mDNS_Dereg_normal, mDNS_Dereg_rapid, mDNS_Dereg_conflict, mDNS_Dereg_repeat } mDNS_Dereg_type;
2759
2760// mDNS_RegisterService is a single call to register the set of resource records associated with a given named service.
2761//
2762//
2763// mDNS_AddRecordToService adds an additional record to a Service Record Set. This record may be deregistered
2764// via mDNS_RemoveRecordFromService, or by deregistering the service. mDNS_RemoveRecordFromService is passed a
2765// callback to free the memory associated with the extra RR when it is safe to do so. The ExtraResourceRecord
2766// object can be found in the record's context pointer.
2767
2768// mDNS_GetBrowseDomains is a special case of the mDNS_StartQuery call, where the resulting answers
2769// are a list of PTR records indicating (in the rdata) domains that are recommended for browsing.
2770// After getting the list of domains to browse, call mDNS_StopQuery to end the search.
2771// mDNS_GetDefaultBrowseDomain returns the name of the domain that should be highlighted by default.
2772//
2773// mDNS_GetRegistrationDomains and mDNS_GetDefaultRegistrationDomain are the equivalent calls to get the list
2774// of one or more domains that should be offered to the user as choices for where they may register their service,
2775// and the default domain in which to register in the case where the user has made no selection.
2776
2777extern void mDNS_SetupResourceRecord(AuthRecord *rr, RData *RDataStorage, mDNSInterfaceID InterfaceID,
2778 mDNSu16 rrtype, mDNSu32 ttl, mDNSu8 RecordType, AuthRecType artype, mDNSRecordCallback Callback, void *Context);

2835#if 0

2839
2840// In order to expose the full capabilities of the DNS protocol (which allows any arbitrary eight-bit values
2841// in domain name labels, including unlikely characters like ascii nulls and even dots) all the mDNS APIs
2842// work with DNS's native length-prefixed strings. For convenience in C, the following utility functions
2843// are provided for converting between C's null-terminated strings and DNS's length-prefixed strings.
2844
2845// Assignment
2846// A simple C structure assignment of a domainname can cause a protection fault by accessing unmapped memory,
2847// because that object is defined to be 256 bytes long, but not all domainname objects are truly the full size.
2848// This macro uses mDNSPlatformMemCopy() to make sure it only touches the actual bytes that are valid.
2849#define AssignDomainName(DST, SRC) do { mDNSu16 len__ = DomainNameLength((SRC)); \
2850 if (len__ <= MAX_DOMAIN_NAME) mDNSPlatformMemCopy((DST)->c, (SRC)->c, len__); else (DST)->c[0] = 0; } while(0)
2851
2852// Comparison functions
2853#define SameDomainLabelCS(A,B) ((A)[0] == (B)[0] && mDNSPlatformMemSame((A)+1, (B)+1, (A)[0]))
2854extern mDNSBool SameDomainLabel(const mDNSu8 *a, const mDNSu8 *b);
2855extern mDNSBool SameDomainName(const domainname *const d1, const domainname *const d2);
2856extern mDNSBool SameDomainNameCS(const domainname *const d1, const domainname *const d2);
2857typedef mDNSBool DomainNameComparisonFn (const domainname *const d1, const domainname *const d2);
2858extern mDNSBool IsLocalDomain(const domainname *d); // returns true for domains that by default should be looked up using link-local multicast
2859
2860#define StripFirstLabel(X) ((const domainname *)& (X)->c[(X)->c[0] ? 1 + (X)->c[0] : 0])
2861
2862#define FirstLabel(X) ((const domainlabel *)(X))
2863#define SecondLabel(X) ((const domainlabel *)StripFirstLabel(X))
2864#define ThirdLabel(X) ((const domainlabel *)StripFirstLabel(StripFirstLabel(X)))
2865
2866extern const mDNSu8 *LastLabel(const domainname *d);
2867
2868// Get total length of domain name, in native DNS format, including terminal root label
2869// (e.g. length of "com." is 5 (length byte, three data bytes, final zero)
2870extern mDNSu16 DomainNameLengthLimit(const domainname *const name, const mDNSu8 *limit);
2871#define DomainNameLength(name) DomainNameLengthLimit((name), (name)->c + MAX_DOMAIN_NAME)
2872
2873// Append functions to append one or more labels to an existing native format domain name:
2874// AppendLiteralLabelString adds a single label from a literal C string, with no escape character interpretation.
2875// AppendDNSNameString adds zero or more labels from a C string using conventional DNS dots-and-escaping interpretation
2876// AppendDomainLabel adds a single label from a native format domainlabel
2877// AppendDomainName adds zero or more labels from a native format domainname
2878extern mDNSu8 *AppendLiteralLabelString(domainname *const name, const char *cstr);
2879extern mDNSu8 *AppendDNSNameString (domainname *const name, const char *cstr);
2880extern mDNSu8 *AppendDomainLabel (domainname *const name, const domainlabel *const label);
2881extern mDNSu8 *AppendDomainName (domainname *const name, const domainname *const append);
2882
2883// Convert from null-terminated string to native DNS format:
2884// The DomainLabel form makes a single label from a literal C string, with no escape character interpretation.
2885// The DomainName form makes native format domain name from a C string using conventional DNS interpretation:
2886// dots separate labels, and within each label, '\.' represents a literal dot, '\\' represents a literal
2887// backslash and backslash with three decimal digits (e.g. \000) represents an arbitrary byte value.
2888extern mDNSBool MakeDomainLabelFromLiteralString(domainlabel *const label, const char *cstr);
2889extern mDNSu8 *MakeDomainNameFromDNSNameString (domainname *const name, const char *cstr);
2890
2891// Convert native format domainlabel or domainname back to C string format
2892// IMPORTANT:
2893// When using ConvertDomainLabelToCString, the target buffer must be MAX_ESCAPED_DOMAIN_LABEL (254) bytes long
2894// to guarantee there will be no buffer overrun. It is only safe to use a buffer shorter than this in rare cases
2895// where the label is known to be constrained somehow (for example, if the label is known to be either "_tcp" or "_udp").
2896// Similarly, when using ConvertDomainNameToCString, the target buffer must be MAX_ESCAPED_DOMAIN_NAME (1009) bytes long.
2897// See definitions of MAX_ESCAPED_DOMAIN_LABEL and MAX_ESCAPED_DOMAIN_NAME for more detailed explanation.
2898extern char *ConvertDomainLabelToCString_withescape(const domainlabel *const name, char *cstr, char esc);
2899#define ConvertDomainLabelToCString_unescaped(D,C) ConvertDomainLabelToCString_withescape((D), (C), 0)
2900#define ConvertDomainLabelToCString(D,C) ConvertDomainLabelToCString_withescape((D), (C), '\\')
2901extern char *ConvertDomainNameToCString_withescape(const domainname *const name, char *cstr, char esc);
2902#define ConvertDomainNameToCString_unescaped(D,C) ConvertDomainNameToCString_withescape((D), (C), 0)
2903#define ConvertDomainNameToCString(D,C) ConvertDomainNameToCString_withescape((D), (C), '\\')
2904
2905extern void ConvertUTF8PstringToRFC1034HostLabel(const mDNSu8 UTF8Name[], domainlabel *const hostlabel);
2906
2907#define ValidTransportProtocol(X) ( (X)[0] == 4 && (X)[1] == '_' && \
2908 ((((X)[2] | 0x20) == 'u' && ((X)[3] | 0x20) == 'd') || (((X)[2] | 0x20) == 't' && ((X)[3] | 0x20) == 'c')) && \
2909 ((X)[4] | 0x20) == 'p')
2910
2911extern mDNSu8 *ConstructServiceName(domainname *const fqdn, const domainlabel *name, const domainname *type, const domainname *const domain);
2912extern mDNSBool DeconstructServiceName(const domainname *const fqdn, domainlabel *const name, domainname *const type, domainname *const domain);

2931// mDNS_vsnprintf/snprintf return the number of characters written, excluding the final terminating null.
2932// The output is always null-terminated: for example, if the output turns out to be exactly buflen long,
2933// then the output will be truncated by one character to allow space for the terminating null.
2934// Unlike standard C vsnprintf/snprintf, they return the number of characters *actually* written,
2935// not the number of characters that *would* have been printed were buflen unlimited.
2936extern mDNSu32 mDNS_vsnprintf(char *sbuffer, mDNSu32 buflen, const char *fmt, va_list arg) IS_A_PRINTF_STYLE_FUNCTION(3,0);
2937extern mDNSu32 mDNS_snprintf(char *sbuffer, mDNSu32 buflen, const char *fmt, ...) IS_A_PRINTF_STYLE_FUNCTION(3,4);
2938extern mDNSu32 NumCacheRecordsForInterfaceID(const mDNS *const m, mDNSInterfaceID id);
2939extern char *DNSTypeName(mDNSu16 rrtype);
2940extern char *GetRRDisplayString_rdb(const ResourceRecord *const rr, const RDataBody *const rd1, char *const buffer);
2941#define RRDisplayString(m, rr) GetRRDisplayString_rdb(rr, &(rr)->rdata->u, (m)->MsgBuffer)
2942#define ARDisplayString(m, rr) GetRRDisplayString_rdb(&(rr)->resrec, &(rr)->resrec.rdata->u, (m)->MsgBuffer)
2943#define CRDisplayString(m, rr) GetRRDisplayString_rdb(&(rr)->resrec, &(rr)->resrec.rdata->u, (m)->MsgBuffer)
2944extern mDNSBool mDNSSameAddress(const mDNSAddr *ip1, const mDNSAddr *ip2);
2945extern void IncrementLabelSuffix(domainlabel *name, mDNSBool RichText);
2946extern mDNSBool mDNSv4AddrIsRFC1918(const mDNSv4Addr * const addr); // returns true for RFC1918 private addresses
2947#define mDNSAddrIsRFC1918(X) ((X)->type == mDNSAddrType_IPv4 && mDNSv4AddrIsRFC1918(&(X)->ip.v4))

2949// For PCP
2950extern void mDNSAddrMapIPv4toIPv6(mDNSv4Addr* in, mDNSv6Addr* out);
2951extern mDNSBool mDNSAddrIPv4FromMappedIPv6(mDNSv6Addr *in, mDNSv4Addr *out);
2952
2953#define mDNSSameIPPort(A,B) ((A).NotAnInteger == (B).NotAnInteger)
2954#define mDNSSameOpaque16(A,B) ((A).NotAnInteger == (B).NotAnInteger)
2955#define mDNSSameOpaque32(A,B) ((A).NotAnInteger == (B).NotAnInteger)
2956#define mDNSSameOpaque64(A,B) ((A)->l[0] == (B)->l[0] && (A)->l[1] == (B)->l[1])
2957
2958#define mDNSSameIPv4Address(A,B) ((A).NotAnInteger == (B).NotAnInteger)
2959#define mDNSSameIPv6Address(A,B) ((A).l[0] == (B).l[0] && (A).l[1] == (B).l[1] && (A).l[2] == (B).l[2] && (A).l[3] == (B).l[3])
2960#define mDNSSameIPv6NetworkPart(A,B) ((A).l[0] == (B).l[0] && (A).l[1] == (B).l[1])
2961#define mDNSSameEthAddress(A,B) ((A)->w[0] == (B)->w[0] && (A)->w[1] == (B)->w[1] && (A)->w[2] == (B)->w[2])
2962
2963#define mDNSIPPortIsZero(A) ((A).NotAnInteger == 0)
2964#define mDNSOpaque16IsZero(A) ((A).NotAnInteger == 0)
2965#define mDNSOpaque64IsZero(A) (((A)->l[0] | (A)->l[1] ) == 0)
2966#define mDNSOpaque128IsZero(A) (((A)->l[0] | (A)->l[1] | (A)->l[2] | (A)->l[3]) == 0)
2967#define mDNSIPv4AddressIsZero(A) ((A).NotAnInteger == 0)
2968#define mDNSIPv6AddressIsZero(A) (((A).l[0] | (A).l[1] | (A).l[2] | (A).l[3]) == 0)
2969#define mDNSEthAddressIsZero(A) (((A).w[0] | (A).w[1] | (A).w[2] ) == 0)
2970
2971#define mDNSIPv4AddressIsOnes(A) ((A).NotAnInteger == 0xFFFFFFFF)
2972#define mDNSIPv6AddressIsOnes(A) (((A).l[0] & (A).l[1] & (A).l[2] & (A).l[3]) == 0xFFFFFFFF)
2973
2974#define mDNSAddressIsAllDNSLinkGroup(X) ( \
2975 ((X)->type == mDNSAddrType_IPv4 && mDNSSameIPv4Address((X)->ip.v4, AllDNSLinkGroup_v4.ip.v4)) || \
2976 ((X)->type == mDNSAddrType_IPv6 && mDNSSameIPv6Address((X)->ip.v6, AllDNSLinkGroup_v6.ip.v6)) )
2977
2978#define mDNSAddressIsZero(X) ( \
2979 ((X)->type == mDNSAddrType_IPv4 && mDNSIPv4AddressIsZero((X)->ip.v4)) || \
2980 ((X)->type == mDNSAddrType_IPv6 && mDNSIPv6AddressIsZero((X)->ip.v6)) )
2981
2982#define mDNSAddressIsValidNonZero(X) ( \
2983 ((X)->type == mDNSAddrType_IPv4 && !mDNSIPv4AddressIsZero((X)->ip.v4)) || \
2984 ((X)->type == mDNSAddrType_IPv6 && !mDNSIPv6AddressIsZero((X)->ip.v6)) )
2985
2986#define mDNSAddressIsOnes(X) ( \
2987 ((X)->type == mDNSAddrType_IPv4 && mDNSIPv4AddressIsOnes((X)->ip.v4)) || \
2988 ((X)->type == mDNSAddrType_IPv6 && mDNSIPv6AddressIsOnes((X)->ip.v6)) )
2989
2990#define mDNSAddressIsValid(X) ( \
2991 ((X)->type == mDNSAddrType_IPv4) ? !(mDNSIPv4AddressIsZero((X)->ip.v4) || mDNSIPv4AddressIsOnes((X)->ip.v4)) : \
2992 ((X)->type == mDNSAddrType_IPv6) ? !(mDNSIPv6AddressIsZero((X)->ip.v6) || mDNSIPv6AddressIsOnes((X)->ip.v6)) : mDNSfalse)
2993
2994#define mDNSv4AddressIsLinkLocal(X) ((X)->b[0] == 169 && (X)->b[1] == 254)
2995#define mDNSv6AddressIsLinkLocal(X) ((X)->b[0] == 0xFE && ((X)->b[1] & 0xC0) == 0x80)
2996
2997#define mDNSAddressIsLinkLocal(X) ( \
2998 ((X)->type == mDNSAddrType_IPv4) ? mDNSv4AddressIsLinkLocal(&(X)->ip.v4) : \
2999 ((X)->type == mDNSAddrType_IPv6) ? mDNSv6AddressIsLinkLocal(&(X)->ip.v6) : mDNSfalse)
3000

3007
3008// Unicast DNS and Dynamic Update specific Client Calls
3009//
3010// mDNS_SetSecretForDomain tells the core to authenticate (via TSIG with an HMAC_MD5 hash of the shared secret)
3011// when dynamically updating a given zone (and its subdomains). The key used in authentication must be in
3012// domain name format. The shared secret must be a null-terminated base64 encoded string. A minimum size of
3013// 16 bytes (128 bits) is recommended for an MD5 hash as per RFC 2485.
3014// Calling this routine multiple times for a zone replaces previously entered values. Call with a NULL key
3015// to disable authentication for the zone. A non-NULL autoTunnelPrefix means this is an AutoTunnel domain,
3016// and the value is prepended to the IPSec identifier (used for key lookup)
3017
3018extern mStatus mDNS_SetSecretForDomain(mDNS *m, DomainAuthInfo *info,
3019 const domainname *domain, const domainname *keyname, const char *b64keydata, const domainname *hostname, mDNSIPPort *port, mDNSBool autoTunnel);
3020
3021extern void RecreateNATMappings(mDNS *const m, const mDNSu32 waitTicks);

3023// Hostname/Unicast Interface Configuration
3024
3025// All hostnames advertised point to one IPv4 address and/or one IPv6 address, set via SetPrimaryInterfaceInfo. Invoking this routine
3026// updates all existing hostnames to point to the new address.
3027
3028// A hostname is added via AddDynDNSHostName, which points to the primary interface's v4 and/or v6 addresss
3029
3030// The status callback is invoked to convey success or failure codes - the callback should not modify the AuthRecord or free memory.
3031// Added hostnames may be removed (deregistered) via mDNS_RemoveDynDNSHostName.
3032
3033// Host domains added prior to specification of the primary interface address and computer name will be deferred until
3034// these values are initialized.
3035
3036// DNS servers used to resolve unicast queries are specified by mDNS_AddDNSServer.
3037// For "split" DNS configurations, in which queries for different domains are sent to different servers (e.g. VPN and external),
3038// a domain may be associated with a DNS server. For standard configurations, specify the root label (".") or NULL.
3039
3040extern void mDNS_AddDynDNSHostName(mDNS *m, const domainname *fqdn, mDNSRecordCallback *StatusCallback, const void *StatusContext);
3041extern void mDNS_RemoveDynDNSHostName(mDNS *m, const domainname *fqdn);
3042extern void mDNS_SetPrimaryInterfaceInfo(mDNS *m, const mDNSAddr *v4addr, const mDNSAddr *v6addr, const mDNSAddr *router);
3043extern DNSServer *mDNS_AddDNSServer(mDNS *const m, const domainname *d, const mDNSInterfaceID interface, mDNSs32 serviceID, const mDNSAddr *addr,
3044 const mDNSIPPort port, mDNSu32 scoped, mDNSu32 timeout, mDNSBool cellIntf, mDNSBool isExpensive, mDNSu16 resGroupID,
3045 mDNSBool reqA, mDNSBool reqAAAA, mDNSBool reqDO);
3046extern void PenalizeDNSServer(mDNS *const m, DNSQuestion *q, mDNSOpaque16 responseFlags);
3047extern void mDNS_AddSearchDomain(const domainname *const domain, mDNSInterfaceID InterfaceID);

3051// We use ((void *)0) here instead of mDNSNULL to avoid compile warnings on gcc 4.2
3052#define mDNS_AddSearchDomain_CString(X, I) \
3053 do { domainname d__; if (((X) != (void*)0) && MakeDomainNameFromDNSNameString(&d__, (X)) && d__.c[0]) mDNS_AddSearchDomain(&d__, I);} while(0)

3055// Routines called by the core, exported by DNSDigest.c
3056
3057// Convert an arbitrary base64 encoded key key into an HMAC key (stored in AuthInfo struct)
3058extern mDNSs32 DNSDigest_ConstructHMACKeyfromBase64(DomainAuthInfo *info, const char *b64key);
3059
3060// sign a DNS message. The message must be complete, with all values in network byte order. end points to the end
3061// of the message, and is modified by this routine. numAdditionals is a pointer to the number of additional
3062// records in HOST byte order, which is incremented upon successful completion of this routine. The function returns
3063// the new end pointer on success, and NULL on failure.
3064extern void DNSDigest_SignMessage(DNSMessage *msg, mDNSu8 **end, DomainAuthInfo *info, mDNSu16 tcode);
3065
3066#define SwapDNSHeaderBytes(M) do { \
3067 (M)->h.numQuestions = (mDNSu16)((mDNSu8 *)&(M)->h.numQuestions )[0] << 8 | ((mDNSu8 *)&(M)->h.numQuestions )[1]; \
3068 (M)->h.numAnswers = (mDNSu16)((mDNSu8 *)&(M)->h.numAnswers )[0] << 8 | ((mDNSu8 *)&(M)->h.numAnswers )[1]; \
3069 (M)->h.numAuthorities = (mDNSu16)((mDNSu8 *)&(M)->h.numAuthorities)[0] << 8 | ((mDNSu8 *)&(M)->h.numAuthorities)[1]; \
3070 (M)->h.numAdditionals = (mDNSu16)((mDNSu8 *)&(M)->h.numAdditionals)[0] << 8 | ((mDNSu8 *)&(M)->h.numAdditionals)[1]; \
3071} while (0)
3072
3073#define DNSDigest_SignMessageHostByteOrder(M,E,INFO) \
3074 do { SwapDNSHeaderBytes(M); DNSDigest_SignMessage((M), (E), (INFO), 0); SwapDNSHeaderBytes(M); } while (0)
3075
3076// verify a DNS message. The message must be complete, with all values in network byte order. end points to the
3077// end of the record. tsig is a pointer to the resource record that contains the TSIG OPT record. info is
3078// the matching key to use for verifying the message. This function expects that the additionals member
3079// of the DNS message header has already had one subtracted from it.
3080extern mDNSBool DNSDigest_VerifyMessage(DNSMessage *msg, mDNSu8 *end, LargeCacheRecord *tsig, DomainAuthInfo *info, mDNSu16 *rcode, mDNSu16 *tcode);

3087
3088// This section defines the interface to the Platform Support layer.
3089// Normal client code should not use any of types defined here, or directly call any of the functions defined here.
3090// The definitions are placed here because sometimes clients do use these calls indirectly, via other supported client operations.
3091// For example, AssignDomainName is a macro defined using mDNSPlatformMemCopy()
3092
3093// Every platform support module must provide the following functions.
3094// mDNSPlatformInit() typically opens a communication endpoint, and starts listening for mDNS packets.
3095// When Setup is complete, the platform support layer calls mDNSCoreInitComplete().
3096// mDNSPlatformSendUDP() sends one UDP packet
3097// When a packet is received, the PlatformSupport code calls mDNSCoreReceive()
3098// mDNSPlatformClose() tidies up on exit
3099//
3100// Note: mDNSPlatformMemAllocate/mDNSPlatformMemFree are only required for handling oversized resource records and unicast DNS.
3101// If your target platform has a well-defined specialized application, and you know that all the records it uses
3102// are InlineCacheRDSize or less, then you can just make a simple mDNSPlatformMemAllocate() stub that always returns
3103// NULL. InlineCacheRDSize is a compile-time constant, which is set by default to 68. If you need to handle records
3104// a little larger than this and you don't want to have to implement run-time allocation and freeing, then you
3105// can raise the value of this constant to a suitable value (at the expense of increased memory usage).
3106//
3107// USE CAUTION WHEN CALLING mDNSPlatformRawTime: The m->timenow_adjust correction factor needs to be added
3108// Generally speaking:
3109// Code that's protected by the main mDNS lock should just use the m->timenow value
3110// Code outside the main mDNS lock should use mDNS_TimeNow(m) to get properly adjusted time
3111// In certain cases there may be reasons why it's necessary to get the time without taking the lock first
3112// (e.g. inside the routines that are doing the locking and unlocking, where a call to get the lock would result in a
3113// recursive loop); in these cases use mDNS_TimeNow_NoLock(m) to get mDNSPlatformRawTime with the proper correction factor added.
3114//
3115// mDNSPlatformUTC returns the time, in seconds, since Jan 1st 1970 UTC and is required for generating TSIG records
3116
3117extern mStatus mDNSPlatformInit (mDNS *const m);
3118extern void mDNSPlatformClose (mDNS *const m);
3119extern mStatus mDNSPlatformSendUDP(const mDNS *const m, const void *const msg, const mDNSu8 *const end,
3120 mDNSInterfaceID InterfaceID, UDPSocket *src, const mDNSAddr *dst,
3121 mDNSIPPort dstport, mDNSBool useBackgroundTrafficClass);
3122
3123extern void mDNSPlatformLock (const mDNS *const m);
3124extern void mDNSPlatformUnlock (const mDNS *const m);
3125
3126extern void mDNSPlatformStrCopy ( void *dst, const void *src);
3127extern mDNSu32 mDNSPlatformStrLCopy ( void *dst, const void *src, mDNSu32 len);
3128extern mDNSu32 mDNSPlatformStrLen ( const void *src);
3129extern void mDNSPlatformMemCopy ( void *dst, const void *src, mDNSu32 len);
3130extern mDNSBool mDNSPlatformMemSame (const void *dst, const void *src, mDNSu32 len);
3131extern int mDNSPlatformMemCmp (const void *dst, const void *src, mDNSu32 len);
3132extern void mDNSPlatformMemZero ( void *dst, mDNSu32 len);
3133extern void mDNSPlatformQsort (void *base, int nel, int width, int (*compar)(const void *, const void *));
3134#if APPLE_OSX_mDNSResponder && MACOSX_MDNS_MALLOC_DEBUGGING
3135#define mDNSPlatformMemAllocate(X) mallocL(# X, X)
3136#else
3137extern void * mDNSPlatformMemAllocate (mDNSu32 len);
3138#endif
3139extern void mDNSPlatformMemFree (void *mem);

3142// from the platform layer. Long-term, we should embed an arc4 implementation, but the strength
3143// will still depend on the randomness of the seed.
3144#if !defined(_PLATFORM_HAS_STRONG_PRNG_) && (_BUILDING_XCODE_PROJECT_ || defined(_WIN32))
3145#define _PLATFORM_HAS_STRONG_PRNG_ 1
3146#endif
3147#if _PLATFORM_HAS_STRONG_PRNG_
3148extern mDNSu32 mDNSPlatformRandomNumber(void);
3149#else
3150extern mDNSu32 mDNSPlatformRandomSeed (void);
3151#endif // _PLATFORM_HAS_STRONG_PRNG_

3153extern mStatus mDNSPlatformTimeInit (void);
3154extern mDNSs32 mDNSPlatformRawTime (void);
3155extern mDNSs32 mDNSPlatformUTC (void);
3156#define mDNS_TimeNow_NoLock(m) (mDNSPlatformRawTime() + (m)->timenow_adjust)

3163// Platform support modules should provide the following functions to map between opaque interface IDs
3164// and interface indexes in order to support the DNS-SD API. If your target platform does not support
3165// multiple interfaces and/or does not support the DNS-SD API, these functions can be empty.

3168
3169// Every platform support module must provide the following functions if it is to support unicast DNS
3170// and Dynamic Update.
3171// All TCP socket operations implemented by the platform layer MUST NOT BLOCK.
3172// mDNSPlatformTCPConnect initiates a TCP connection with a peer, adding the socket descriptor to the
3173// main event loop. The return value indicates whether the connection succeeded, failed, or is pending
3174// (i.e. the call would block.) On return, the descriptor parameter is set to point to the connected socket.
3175// The TCPConnectionCallback is subsequently invoked when the connection
3176// completes (in which case the ConnectionEstablished parameter is true), or data is available for
3177// reading on the socket (indicated by the ConnectionEstablished parameter being false.) If the connection
3178// asynchronously fails, the TCPConnectionCallback should be invoked as usual, with the error being
3179// returned in subsequent calls to PlatformReadTCP or PlatformWriteTCP. (This allows for platforms
3180// with limited asynchronous error detection capabilities.) PlatformReadTCP and PlatformWriteTCP must
3181// return the number of bytes read/written, 0 if the call would block, and -1 if an error. PlatformReadTCP
3182// should set the closed argument if the socket has been closed.
3183// PlatformTCPCloseConnection must close the connection to the peer and remove the descriptor from the
3184// event loop. CloseConnectin may be called at any time, including in a ConnectionCallback.
3185
3186typedef enum
3187{
3188 kTCPSocketFlags_Zero = 0,
3189 kTCPSocketFlags_UseTLS = (1 << 0)
3190} TCPSocketFlags;
3191
3192typedef void (*TCPConnectionCallback)(TCPSocket *sock, void *context, mDNSBool ConnectionEstablished, mStatus err);
3193extern TCPSocket *mDNSPlatformTCPSocket(TCPSocketFlags flags, mDNSIPPort *port, mDNSBool useBackgroundTrafficClass); // creates a TCP socket
3194extern TCPSocket *mDNSPlatformTCPAccept(TCPSocketFlags flags, int sd);
3195extern int mDNSPlatformTCPGetFD(TCPSocket *sock);
3196extern mStatus mDNSPlatformTCPConnect(TCPSocket *sock, const mDNSAddr *dst, mDNSOpaque16 dstport, domainname *hostname,
3197 mDNSInterfaceID InterfaceID, TCPConnectionCallback callback, void *context);
3198extern void mDNSPlatformTCPCloseConnection(TCPSocket *sock);
3199extern long mDNSPlatformReadTCP(TCPSocket *sock, void *buf, unsigned long buflen, mDNSBool *closed);
3200extern long mDNSPlatformWriteTCP(TCPSocket *sock, const char *msg, unsigned long len);
3201extern UDPSocket *mDNSPlatformUDPSocket(const mDNSIPPort requestedport);
3202extern mDNSu16 mDNSPlatformGetUDPPort(UDPSocket *sock);
3203extern void mDNSPlatformUDPClose(UDPSocket *sock);
3204extern mDNSBool mDNSPlatformUDPSocketEncounteredEOF(const UDPSocket *sock);
3205extern void mDNSPlatformReceiveBPF_fd(int fd);
3206extern void mDNSPlatformUpdateProxyList(const mDNSInterfaceID InterfaceID);
3207extern void mDNSPlatformSendRawPacket(const void *const msg, const mDNSu8 *const end, mDNSInterfaceID InterfaceID);
3208extern void mDNSPlatformSetLocalAddressCacheEntry(const mDNSAddr *const tpa, const mDNSEthAddr *const tha, mDNSInterfaceID InterfaceID);
3209extern void mDNSPlatformSourceAddrForDest(mDNSAddr *const src, const mDNSAddr *const dst);
3210extern void mDNSPlatformSendKeepalive(mDNSAddr *sadd, mDNSAddr *dadd, mDNSIPPort *lport, mDNSIPPort *rport, mDNSu32 seq, mDNSu32 ack, mDNSu16 win);
3211extern mStatus mDNSPlatformRetrieveTCPInfo(mDNSAddr *laddr, mDNSIPPort *lport, mDNSAddr *raddr, mDNSIPPort *rport, mDNSTCPInfo *mti);
3212extern mStatus mDNSPlatformGetRemoteMacAddr(mDNSAddr *raddr);

3214extern mStatus mDNSPlatformClearSPSData(void);
3215extern mStatus mDNSPlatformStoreOwnerOptRecord(char *ifname, DNSMessage *msg, int length);

3250
3251// The core mDNS code provides these functions, for the platform support code to call at appropriate times
3252//
3253// mDNS_SetFQDN() is called once on startup (typically from mDNSPlatformInit())
3254// and then again on each subsequent change of the host name.
3255//
3256// mDNS_RegisterInterface() is used by the platform support layer to inform mDNSCore of what
3257// physical and/or logical interfaces are available for sending and receiving packets.
3258// Typically it is called on startup for each available interface, but register/deregister may be
3259// called again later, on multiple occasions, to inform the core of interface configuration changes.
3260// If set->Advertise is set non-zero, then mDNS_RegisterInterface() also registers the standard
3261// resource records that should be associated with every publicised IP address/interface:
3262// -- Name-to-address records (A/AAAA)
3263// -- Address-to-name records (PTR)
3264// -- Host information (HINFO)
3265// IMPORTANT: The specified mDNSInterfaceID MUST NOT be 0, -1, or -2; these values have special meaning
3266// mDNS_RegisterInterface does not result in the registration of global hostnames via dynamic update -
3267// see mDNS_SetPrimaryInterfaceInfo, mDNS_AddDynDNSHostName, etc. for this purpose.
3268// Note that the set may be deallocated immediately after it is deregistered via mDNS_DeegisterInterface.
3269//
3270// mDNS_RegisterDNS() is used by the platform support layer to provide the core with the addresses of
3271// available domain name servers for unicast queries/updates. RegisterDNS() should be called once for
3272// each name server, typically at startup, or when a new name server becomes available. DeregiterDNS()
3273// must be called whenever a registered name server becomes unavailable. DeregisterDNSList deregisters
3274// all registered servers. mDNS_DNSRegistered() returns true if one or more servers are registered in the core.
3275//
3276// mDNSCoreInitComplete() is called when the platform support layer is finished.
3277// Typically this is at the end of mDNSPlatformInit(), but may be later
3278// (on platforms like OT that allow asynchronous initialization of the networking stack).
3279//
3280// mDNSCoreReceive() is called when a UDP packet is received
3281//
3282// mDNSCoreMachineSleep() is called when the machine sleeps or wakes
3283// (This refers to heavyweight laptop-style sleep/wake that disables network access,
3284// not lightweight second-by-second CPU power management modes.)
3285
3286extern void mDNS_SetFQDN(mDNS *const m);
3287extern void mDNS_ActivateNetWake_internal (mDNS *const m, NetworkInterfaceInfo *set);
3288extern void mDNS_DeactivateNetWake_internal(mDNS *const m, NetworkInterfaceInfo *set);
3289
3290// Attributes that controls the Bonjour operation initiation and response speed for an interface.
3291typedef enum
3292{
3293 FastActivation, // For p2p* and DirectLink type interfaces
3294 NormalActivation, // For standard interface timing
3295 SlowActivation // For flapping interfaces
3296} InterfaceActivationSpeed;
3297
3298extern mStatus mDNS_RegisterInterface (mDNS *const m, NetworkInterfaceInfo *set, InterfaceActivationSpeed probeDelay);
3299extern void mDNS_DeregisterInterface(mDNS *const m, NetworkInterfaceInfo *set, InterfaceActivationSpeed probeDelay);
3300extern void mDNSCoreInitComplete(mDNS *const m, mStatus result);
3301extern void mDNSCoreReceive(mDNS *const m, DNSMessage *const msg, const mDNSu8 *const end,
3302 const mDNSAddr *const srcaddr, const mDNSIPPort srcport,
3303 const mDNSAddr *dstaddr, const mDNSIPPort dstport, const mDNSInterfaceID InterfaceID);
3304extern void mDNSCoreRestartQueries(mDNS *const m);
3305extern void mDNSCoreRestartQuestion(mDNS *const m, DNSQuestion *q);
3306extern void mDNSCoreRestartRegistration(mDNS *const m, AuthRecord *rr, int announceCount);

3387#if 0
3388#pragma mark -
3389#pragma mark - Sleep Proxy
3390#endif
3391
3392// Sleep Proxy Server Property Encoding
3393//
3394// Sleep Proxy Servers are advertised using a structured service name, consisting of four
3395// metrics followed by a human-readable name. The metrics assist clients in deciding which
3396// Sleep Proxy Server(s) to use when multiple are available on the network. Each metric
3397// is a two-digit decimal number in the range 10-99. Lower metrics are generally better.
3398//
3399// AA-BB-CC-DD.FF Name
3400//
3401// Metrics:
3402//
3403// AA = Intent
3404// BB = Portability
3405// CC = Marginal Power
3406// DD = Total Power
3407// FF = Features Supported (Currently TCP Keepalive only)
3408//
3409//
3410// ** Intent Metric **
3411//
3412// 20 = Dedicated Sleep Proxy Server -- a device, permanently powered on,
3413// installed for the express purpose of providing Sleep Proxy Service.
3414//
3415// 30 = Primary Network Infrastructure Hardware -- a router, DHCP server, NAT gateway,
3416// or similar permanently installed device which is permanently powered on.
3417// This is hardware designed for the express purpose of being network
3418// infrastructure, and for most home users is typically a single point
3419// of failure for the local network -- e.g. most home users only have
3420// a single NAT gateway / DHCP server. Even though in principle the
3421// hardware might technically be capable of running different software,
3422// a typical user is unlikely to do that. e.g. AirPort base station.
3423//
3424// 40 = Primary Network Infrastructure Software -- a general-purpose computer
3425// (e.g. Mac, Windows, Linux, etc.) which is currently running DHCP server
3426// or NAT gateway software, but the user could choose to turn that off
3427// fairly easily. e.g. iMac running Internet Sharing
3428//
3429// 50 = Secondary Network Infrastructure Hardware -- like primary infrastructure
3430// hardware, except not a single point of failure for the entire local network.
3431// For example, an AirPort base station in bridge mode. This may have clients
3432// associated with it, and if it goes away those clients will be inconvenienced,
3433// but unlike the NAT gateway / DHCP server, the entire local network is not
3434// dependent on it.
3435//
3436// 60 = Secondary Network Infrastructure Software -- like 50, but in a general-
3437// purpose CPU.
3438//
3439// 70 = Incidentally Available Hardware -- a device which has no power switch
3440// and is generally left powered on all the time. Even though it is not a
3441// part of what we conventionally consider network infrastructure (router,
3442// DHCP, NAT, DNS, etc.), and the rest of the network can operate fine
3443// without it, since it's available and unlikely to be turned off, it is a
3444// reasonable candidate for providing Sleep Proxy Service e.g. Apple TV,
3445// or an AirPort base station in client mode, associated with an existing
3446// wireless network (e.g. AirPort Express connected to a music system, or
3447// being used to share a USB printer).
3448//
3449// 80 = Incidentally Available Software -- a general-purpose computer which
3450// happens at this time to be set to "never sleep", and as such could be
3451// useful as a Sleep Proxy Server, but has not been intentionally provided
3452// for this purpose. Of all the Intent Metric categories this is the
3453// one most likely to be shut down or put to sleep without warning.
3454// However, if nothing else is availalable, it may be better than nothing.
3455// e.g. Office computer in the workplace which has been set to "never sleep"
3456//
3457//
3458// ** Portability Metric **
3459//
3460// Inversely related to mass of device, on the basis that, all other things
3461// being equal, heavier devices are less likely to be moved than lighter devices.
3462// E.g. A MacBook running Internet Sharing is probably more likely to be
3463// put to sleep and taken away than a Mac Pro running Internet Sharing.
3464// The Portability Metric is a logarithmic decibel scale, computed by taking the
3465// (approximate) mass of the device in milligrammes, taking the base 10 logarithm
3466// of that, multiplying by 10, and subtracting the result from 100:
3467//
3468// Portability Metric = 100 - (log10(mg) * 10)
3469//
3470// The Portability Metric is not necessarily computed literally from the actual
3471// mass of the device; the intent is just that lower numbers indicate more
3472// permanent devices, and higher numbers indicate devices more likely to be
3473// removed from the network, e.g., in order of increasing portability:
3474//
3475// Mac Pro < iMac < Laptop < iPhone
3476//
3477// Example values:
3478//
3479// 10 = 1 metric tonne
3480// 40 = 1kg
3481// 70 = 1g
3482// 90 = 10mg
3483//
3484//
3485// ** Marginal Power and Total Power Metrics **
3486//
3487// The Marginal Power Metric is the power difference between sleeping and staying awake
3488// to be a Sleep Proxy Server.
3489//
3490// The Total Power Metric is the total power consumption when being Sleep Proxy Server.
3491//
3492// The Power Metrics use a logarithmic decibel scale, computed as ten times the
3493// base 10 logarithm of the (approximate) power in microwatts:
3494//
3495// Power Metric = log10(uW) * 10
3496//
3497// Higher values indicate higher power consumption. Example values:
3498//
3499// 10 = 10 uW
3500// 20 = 100 uW
3501// 30 = 1 mW
3502// 60 = 1 W
3503// 90 = 1 kW
3504
3505typedef enum
3506{
3507 mDNSSleepProxyMetric_Dedicated = 20,
3508 mDNSSleepProxyMetric_PrimaryHardware = 30,
3509 mDNSSleepProxyMetric_PrimarySoftware = 40,
3510 mDNSSleepProxyMetric_SecondaryHardware = 50,
3511 mDNSSleepProxyMetric_SecondarySoftware = 60,
3512 mDNSSleepProxyMetric_IncidentalHardware = 70,
3513 mDNSSleepProxyMetric_IncidentalSoftware = 80
3514} mDNSSleepProxyMetric;
3515
3516typedef enum
3517{
3518 mDNS_NoWake = 0, // System does not support Wake on LAN
3519 mDNS_WakeOnAC = 1, // System supports Wake on LAN when connected to AC power only
3520 mDNS_WakeOnBattery = 2 // System supports Wake on LAN on battery
3521} mDNSWakeForNetworkAccess;
3522
3523extern void mDNSCoreBeSleepProxyServer_internal(mDNS *const m, mDNSu8 sps, mDNSu8 port, mDNSu8 marginalpower, mDNSu8 totpower, mDNSu8 features);
3524#define mDNSCoreBeSleepProxyServer(M,S,P,MP,TP,F) \
3525 do { mDNS_Lock(m); mDNSCoreBeSleepProxyServer_internal((M),(S),(P),(MP),(TP),(F)); mDNS_Unlock(m); } while(0)
3526
3527extern void FindSPSInCache(mDNS *const m, const DNSQuestion *const q, const CacheRecord *sps[3]);
3528#define PrototypeSPSName(X) ((X)[0] >= 11 && (X)[3] == '-' && (X)[ 4] == '9' && (X)[ 5] == '9' && \
3529 (X)[6] == '-' && (X)[ 7] == '9' && (X)[ 8] == '9' && \
3530 (X)[9] == '-' && (X)[10] == '9' && (X)[11] == '9' )
3531#define ValidSPSName(X) ((X)[0] >= 5 && mDNSIsDigit((X)[1]) && mDNSIsDigit((X)[2]) && mDNSIsDigit((X)[4]) && mDNSIsDigit((X)[5]))
3532#define SPSMetric(X) (!ValidSPSName(X) || PrototypeSPSName(X) ? 1000000 : \
3533 ((X)[1]-'0') * 100000 + ((X)[2]-'0') * 10000 + ((X)[4]-'0') * 1000 + ((X)[5]-'0') * 100 + ((X)[7]-'0') * 10 + ((X)[8]-'0'))
3534#define LocalSPSMetric(X) ( (X)->SPSType * 10000 + (X)->SPSPortability * 100 + (X)->SPSMarginalPower)
3535#define SPSFeatures(X) ((X)[0] >= 13 && (X)[12] =='.' ? ((X)[13]-'0') : 0 )
3536
3537#define MD5_DIGEST_LENGTH 16 /* digest length in bytes */
3538#define MD5_BLOCK_BYTES 64 /* block size in bytes */
3539#define MD5_BLOCK_LONG (MD5_BLOCK_BYTES / sizeof(mDNSu32))
3540
3541typedef struct MD5state_st
3542{
3543 mDNSu32 A,B,C,D;
3544 mDNSu32 Nl,Nh;
3545 mDNSu32 data[MD5_BLOCK_LONG];
3546 int num;
3547} MD5_CTX;
3548

3550extern int MD5_Update(MD5_CTX *c, const void *data, unsigned long len);
3551extern int MD5_Final(unsigned char *md, MD5_CTX *c);

3554#if 0
3555#pragma mark -
3556#pragma mark - Compile-Time assertion checks
3557#endif
3558
3559// Some C compiler cleverness. We can make the compiler check certain things for
3560// us, and report compile-time errors if anything is wrong. The usual way to do
3561// this would be to use a run-time "if" statement, but then you don't find out
3562// what's wrong until you run the software. This way, if the assertion condition
3563// is false, the array size is negative, and the complier complains immediately.
3564
3565struct CompileTimeAssertionChecks_mDNS
3566{
3567#ifndef __lint__
3568 // Check that the compiler generated our on-the-wire packet format structure definitions
3569 // properly packed, without adding padding bytes to align fields on 32-bit or 64-bit boundaries.
3570 char assert0[(sizeof(rdataSRV) == 262 ) ? 1 : -1];
3571 char assert1[(sizeof(DNSMessageHeader) == 12 ) ? 1 : -1];
3572 char assert2[(sizeof(DNSMessage) == 12+AbsoluteMaxDNSMessageData) ? 1 : -1];
3573 char assert3[(sizeof(mDNSs8) == 1 ) ? 1 : -1];
3574 char assert4[(sizeof(mDNSu8) == 1 ) ? 1 : -1];
3575 char assert5[(sizeof(mDNSs16) == 2 ) ? 1 : -1];
3576 char assert6[(sizeof(mDNSu16) == 2 ) ? 1 : -1];
3577 char assert7[(sizeof(mDNSs32) == 4 ) ? 1 : -1];
3578 char assert8[(sizeof(mDNSu32) == 4 ) ? 1 : -1];
3579 char assert9[(sizeof(mDNSOpaque16) == 2 ) ? 1 : -1];
3580 char assertA[(sizeof(mDNSOpaque32) == 4 ) ? 1 : -1];
3581 char assertB[(sizeof(mDNSOpaque128) == 16 ) ? 1 : -1];
3582 char assertC[(sizeof(CacheRecord ) == sizeof(CacheGroup) ) ? 1 : -1];
3583 char assertD[(sizeof(int) >= 4 ) ? 1 : -1];
3584 char assertE[(StandardAuthRDSize >= 256 ) ? 1 : -1];
3585 char assertF[(sizeof(EthernetHeader) == 14 ) ? 1 : -1];
3586 char assertG[(sizeof(ARP_EthIP ) == 28 ) ? 1 : -1];
3587 char assertH[(sizeof(IPv4Header ) == 20 ) ? 1 : -1];
3588 char assertI[(sizeof(IPv6Header ) == 40 ) ? 1 : -1];
3589 char assertJ[(sizeof(IPv6NDP ) == 24 ) ? 1 : -1];
3590 char assertK[(sizeof(UDPHeader ) == 8 ) ? 1 : -1];
3591 char assertL[(sizeof(IKEHeader ) == 28 ) ? 1 : -1];
3592 char assertM[(sizeof(TCPHeader ) == 20 ) ? 1 : -1];
3593 char assertN[(sizeof(rdataOPT) == 24 ) ? 1 : -1];
3594 char assertO[(sizeof(rdataRRSig) == 20 ) ? 1 : -1];
3595 char assertP[(sizeof(PCPMapRequest) == 60 ) ? 1 : -1];
3596 char assertQ[(sizeof(PCPMapReply) == 60 ) ? 1 : -1];
3597
3598
3599 // Check our structures are reasonable sizes. Including overly-large buffers, or embedding
3600 // other overly-large structures instead of having a pointer to them, can inadvertently
3601 // cause structure sizes (and therefore memory usage) to balloon unreasonably.
3602 char sizecheck_RDataBody [(sizeof(RDataBody) == 264) ? 1 : -1];
3603 char sizecheck_ResourceRecord [(sizeof(ResourceRecord) <= 72) ? 1 : -1];
3604 char sizecheck_AuthRecord [(sizeof(AuthRecord) <= 1208) ? 1 : -1];
3605 char sizecheck_CacheRecord [(sizeof(CacheRecord) <= 232) ? 1 : -1];
3606 char sizecheck_CacheGroup [(sizeof(CacheGroup) <= 232) ? 1 : -1];
3607 char sizecheck_DNSQuestion [(sizeof(DNSQuestion) <= 912) ? 1 : -1];
3608
3609 char sizecheck_ZoneData [(sizeof(ZoneData) <= 1744) ? 1 : -1];
3610 char sizecheck_NATTraversalInfo [(sizeof(NATTraversalInfo) <= 200) ? 1 : -1];
3611 char sizecheck_HostnameInfo [(sizeof(HostnameInfo) <= 3050) ? 1 : -1];
3612 char sizecheck_DNSServer [(sizeof(DNSServer) <= 330) ? 1 : -1];
3613 char sizecheck_NetworkInterfaceInfo[(sizeof(NetworkInterfaceInfo) <= 7376) ? 1 : -1];
3614 char sizecheck_ServiceRecordSet [(sizeof(ServiceRecordSet) <= 5540) ? 1 : -1];
3615 char sizecheck_DomainAuthInfo [(sizeof(DomainAuthInfo) <= 7888) ? 1 : -1];
3616#if APPLE_OSX_mDNSResponder
3617 char sizecheck_ClientTunnel [(sizeof(ClientTunnel) <= 1256) ? 1 : -1];
3618#endif
3619#endif
3620};
